content.text: Write \(80\mathrm{kg}\) as a fraction of the total mass of tomatoes and grapes
Give your answer in its lowest terms
Write down the ratio mass of tomatoes: mass of grapes
Give your answer in its simplest form
In one week, David sells \(120\mathrm{kg}\) of tomatoes and \(80\mathrm{kg}\) of grapes
One day he sells \(28\mathrm{kg}\) of oranges at \(\$ 1.56\) per kilogram
The total he receives from selling the oranges and the apples is \(\$ 86.38\)
Calculate the price of 1 kilogram of apples
The price of 1 kilogram of oranges is \(\$ 1.56\)
This is \(20\%\) more than the price two weeks ago
Calculate the price two weeks ago
On another day, David received a total of \(\$ 667\) from all the fruit he sold
The cost of the fruit was \(\$ 314.20\)
David worked for \(10\frac{1}{2}\) hours on this day
Calculate David's rate of profit in dollars per hour
David sells fruit at the market
On the grid, draw a speed-time graph to show Emily's journey
Calculate Emily's average speed for the journey
Emily cycles along a path for 2 minutes
She starts from rest and accelerates at a constant rate until she reaches a speed of \(5 \text{m/s}\) after 40 seconds
She continues cycling at \(5 \text{m/s}\) for 60 seconds
She then decelerates at a constant rate until she stops after a further 20 seconds
Calculate the curved surface area of the cone
[The curved surface area, \(A\), of a cone with radius \(r\) and slant height \(l\) is \(A = \pi r l\).]
Calculate the perpendicular height, \(h\), of the cone
Calculate the volume of the cone
[The volume, \(V,\) of a cone with radius \(r\) and height \(h\) is \(V = \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h.\)]
Write your answer to part (a)(iii) in cubic metres
Give your answer in standard form
The diagram shows a cone of radius \(5\mathrm{cm}\) and slant height \(13\mathrm{cm}\)
The cone is now cut along a slant height and it opens out to make the sector \(AOB\) of a circle
Calculate the area of the playground \(ABCD\)
An accurate plan of the school playground is to be drawn to a scale of 1:200
Calculate the area of the school playground on the plan
A fence, \(BD,\) divides the playground into two areas
Calculate the shortest distance from \(A\) to \(BD\)
The diagram shows a school playground \(ABCD\)
Draw the reflection of triangle \(T\) in the line \(y = 5\)
Draw the rotation of triangle \(T\) about the point (4, 2) through \(180^{\circ}\)
Describe fully the **single** transformation that maps triangle \(T\) onto triangle \(U\)
Find the \(2 \times 2\) matrix which represents the transformation in **part (a)(iii)**
In the pentagon \(OPQRS\), \(OP\) is parallel to \(RQ\) and \(OS\) is parallel to \(PQ\)
Find, in terms of \(\mathbf{p}\) and \(\mathbf{s}\), in their simplest form,
Explain what your answers in **part (b)** tell you about the lines \(OQ\) and \(SR\)
Write down the value of the largest **integer**, \(k\), for which the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x) = k\) has 3 solutions
By drawing a suitable straight line, solve the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x) = x\)
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) for \(-3 \leqslant x \leqslant 3\)
Calculate an estimate of the mean time
On the grid below, draw a cumulative frequency diagram to show this information
Use your cumulative frequency diagram to find the median, the lower quartile the 60th percentile
Use the information in the **frequency table** on the opposite page to complete this new table
On the grid below, complete the histogram to show the information in the new table
One column has already been drawn for you
The intervals for the times taken are changed
120 students are asked to answer a question
The time, \(t\) seconds, taken by each student to answer the question is measured
The frequency table shows the results
Show all your working and give your answers correct to 2 decimal places
\(y\) varies directly as the square root of \(x\)
Sara spends \(\$ x\) on pens which cost \(\$ 2.50\) each
She also spends \(\$ (x - 14.50)\) on pencils which cost \(\$ 0.50\) each
The **total** of the number of pens and the number of pencils is 19
Write down and solve an equation in \(x\)
Find the equations of the lines \(L_{1}, L_{2}\) and \(L_{3}\)
Write down the three inequalities that define the shaded region, \(R\)
Find the number of bushes and the number of trees when the total cost is \(\)720
Find the number of bushes and the number of trees which give the greatest possible total cost
Write down this greatest possible total cost
A gardener buys \(x\) bushes and \(y\) trees
The cost of a bush is \(30 and the cost of a tree is\) 200
The shaded region \(R\) shows the only possible numbers of bushes and trees the gardener can buy
Write down the next line of this pattern
The sum of the first \(n\) integers is \(\frac{n}{k} (n + 1)\)
Find the sum of the first 60 integers
Find \(n\) when the sum of the first \(n\) integers is 465
The sum of the first \(n\) integers is \(\frac{n}{2} (n + 1)\)
Find an expression, in terms of \(n\), for the sum of the first \(n\) cubes
Find the sum of the first 19 cubes
